edge: The film 'Gotti' is about the American mobster John Gotti, portrayed by actor John Travolta in this biographical crime drama.
In the film 'Gotti', Kelly Preston plays Victoria, who is John Gotti's real-life wife.
Barry Levinson was originally announced as one of the directors for this film but later dropped out.
Al Pacino was also associated with this project earlier as one of the actors but later withdrew.
Initially, Lionsgate had acquired the distribution rights for this film, but they eventually returned these rights to the producers and studio due to some unknown reasons.
SunRider Productions is one of the production companies associated with this movie.
Vertical Entertainment is another production company involved in making this film. They also played a crucial role in releasing it after acquiring its distribution rights from Lionsgate.
This film had its premiere at the 2018 edition of Cannes Film Festival.
Gotti was a notorious mob boss in New York City, as portrayed in the movie. In the film, John Gotti addresses the audience, reflecting on his lengthy reign of crime in New York City.
In 1973, Aniello 'Neil' Dellacroce, underboss to the Gambino crime family, tasks Gotti, a young associate, with killing gangster James McBratney, as portrayed in the movie.
Gotti executed McBratney at a bar, as portrayed in the movie, who is believed to have kidnapped and murdered boss Carlo Gambino's nephew Emanuel.
After executing McBratney in 1973, as portrayed in the movie, Gotti was identified as his killer and sentenced to 4 years at Green Haven Correctional Facility the following year.

Due to the influence of the Gambino family, as portrayed in the movie, Gotti was released on 'medical furloughs' both for appointments with the family's dentist and for conducting further criminal business while in prison.
Paroled in July 1977 after 2 years, as portrayed in the movie, he reunites with his wife Victoria and children at their new residence in Howard Beach, Queens.
Immediately climbing the Mafia hierarchy to become a capo, as portrayed in the movie.
Gotti operates out of the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club with his childhood friend Angelo Ruggiero.

node_2: lucchese crime family's top underboss, anthony casso
edge: Gotti mistrusts the Lucchese crime family's top underboss, Anthony Casso.
His next-door neighbor accidentally strikes and kills Frank Gotti on March 18, and the only witness to his abduction, diner owner Leon Papon, is intimidated into silence.
Gotti becomes convinced that family boss Paul Castellano is too frail to lead effectively.
Junior instigates a bar brawl that results in a man's death, infuriating his father.

Prosecutor Diane Giacalone, assistant attorney for the Eastern District of New York, discloses that his close associate, Wilfred 'Willy Boy' Johnson, has been a confidential informant for the FBI since 1966; he agrees to give him a reprieve for betraying the family, but does not object when Johnson is eventually murdered on August 29, 1988.

Gotti informs Dellacroce about Castellano's plans to disband Gotti's crew due to his insubordination. Later, Gotti helps secure the approval of the Five Families for eliminating Castellano after he fails to attend Dellacroce's funeral.

Dellacroce informs Gotti about Castellano's plans to disband Gotti's crew due to his insubordination. Dellacroce also helps secure the approval of the Five Families for eliminating Castellano after he fails to attend Dellacroce's funeral.
DeCicco is killed by a car bomb that Ruggiero believes was meant for Gotti. This incident creates a rift between Casso and Ruggiero, which leads to further retribution.

Gotti excommunicates Ruggiero from his crew to shield him from further retribution. This decision is made after Casso survives an unsanctioned hit and tracks down the hitman, James Hydell, into revealing he was sent by Ruggiero.
Gotti reconciles with Gigante before excommunicating Ruggiero from his crew. This reconciliation is made to shield Gigiante from further retribution.
Dellacroce informs Castellano about his plans to reorganize the Gambino family. Later, after Dellacroce's death, Castellano fails to attend the funeral.
Escaping prosecution for the third time in 1987, Gotti is nicknamed 'the Teflon Don' for being untouchable by the law.
Gotti is charged with organizing Castellano's murder in trial in 1992 for the fourth time.
Underboss Gravano testifies against Gotti, and this time, Gotti is convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment without parole.
Several family members are killed when rivals target the organization.

After Gotti dies on June 10, 2002 from throat cancer, Junior chooses to abandon his criminal life for his own family's sake, and after five trials, he is finally released from prison in December 2009.
Gotti dies on June 10, 2002 from throat cancer.
In September 2010, Fiore Films announced that it had secured the rights from Gotti Jr. To produce a film about his life.

edge: Nick Cassavetes and Joe Johnston were then also attached at different points to direct, as were Al Pacino, Lindsay Lohan, and Ben Foster to star in various roles.
Joe Pesci was cast as Angelo Ruggiero early in development and gained 30 pounds in order to properly portray him.
After having his salary cut and being recast as Lucchese underboss Anthony Casso, he sued Fiore Films for $3 million; the case was settled out of court.
Chazz Palminteri, who had played Paul Castellano in the TNT made-for-TV film Boss of Bosses, was also initially cast to reprise Gotti's predecessor.
Emmett/Furla/Oasis Films, Fiore Films and Herrick Entertainment would be financing the film,
with Lionsgate Premiere handling the domestic distribution rights.
The film, Gotti, premiered at the Cannes Film Festival on May 15, 2018.
Gotti grossed $6.1 million worldwide, against a production budget of $10 million.
Gotti grossed $4.3 million in the United States.
The production budget of Gotti was $10 million.
MoviePass Ventures, a subsidiary of MoviePass, acquired an equity stake in the film.
MoviePass Ventures will participate in the revenue generated from the film.
Vertical Entertainment was the film's new distributor.
On March 12, 2018, Connolly announced that the film would be released on June 15, 2018.
The film was originally set to be released in a limited release and through video on demand on December 15, 2017, through Lionsgate Premiere.
Producers began seeking a new distributor in order for the film to receive a wide theatrical release, as opposed to the original release it was initially intended to have.

The film 'Gotti' validates the criticism that mob movies invariably glorify their subjects, as noted by Nick Schager from The Daily Beast. This implies a relationship between Gotti and mob movie where Gotti is being characterized as an example of how mob movies glorify their subjects.
Nick Schager from The Daily Beast described Gotti as a noble and ruthless warrior-leader who was good for the community because he only killed his own and kept a lid on neighborhood crime.
Richard Roeper of the Chicago Sun-Times referred to 'Gotti' as an uneven B-movie and a mob-movie misfire during his review.

During the opening weekend, there was a large disparity on Rotten Tomatoes between the audience approval score of 80% and the 0% critics' score. This suggests that 'Gotti' has a relationship with both Rotten Tomatoes and the concepts of audience approval score and critics' score.
As of now, the audience approval score on Rotten Tomatoes for 'Gotti' has dropped by 36 points to a score of 44%.

Accusations against the production studio and marketing team increased after Dan Murrell of Screen Junkies noted that the disparity between audience and critic reception of Gotti made no sense and suspected vote manipulation on behalf of the studio.

Observers noted the abnormally high number of negative reviews for Gotti compared to other films that did better at the box office that weekend, such as Incredibles 2. This led some to question why critics didn't want audiences to see the film.

The production studio and marketing team launched a campaign proclaiming that 'Audiences loved Gotti but critics don't want you to see it ... The question is why? Trust the people and see it for yourself!' This was suspected by some to be an attempt to hit back at the critics.

The production studio and marketing team accused critics of trying to prevent audiences from seeing Gotti, with observers noting that the high number of reviews for the film compared unfavorably to other films that did better at the box office.
Rotten Tomatoes staff issued a statement stating they didn't find any evidence of tampering and that 'All of the ratings and reviews were left by active accounts.'

In June 2018, it was noted that 32 of the 54 written reviews were found to be from first-time reviewers on the site, who had also only left a review for Gotti itself,
